review_title: Large corporation / Competency of store's management matters a lot
pros:
- Benefits are actually good.

- Room to advance, and they flexible with you choosing your own desired career path.

- The type of place where your co-workers are one of the best things to count toward the pros column.
cons:
- Training at my store was pretty bad. Lack of guidance at ALL levels in the leadership structure led to weaknesses that could have been prevented through adequate training.

- Those who could perform are leaned on to compensate for those who couldn't. An environment rife for burnout.

- Wages do not meet fair market value for the work output expected. Plenty of places paying more for people who prove they know how to work.

pros:
Nice benefits once you understand them. 
Almost impossible to be terminated (also on the cons list).
I have met some really great people working there.
cons:
Management mostly stays out of sight, which is frustrating when issues are beyond your ability to fix. Most likely to see them when things are slow in the evening and they have nit picking to do. 
Many managers literally have no idea what is going on. They don’t have many prerequisites (learning how some of the more  difficult departments operate might be nice).
Lots of blatant, unchecked bias in management.
Have to practically beg for any form of recognition. 
Most associates take advantage of the lack of consequences, making others pick up the slack. You basically have to TRY to get fired or receive any kind of disciplinary action. Not the best place for someone to stay long term. Not if you want honest opportunity for growth. Your proven skills and experience will not help you get that open position you nailed the interviewed for. Management puts you (or keeps you) where they want you. 
“Orange values” are just buzz words to make associates feel like a part of something bigger. Leadership does not live by these values.

pros:
Easy application process
Lots of new hires
cons: Horrible management culture. The managers put too much pressure on management below them which creates a toxic environment for all workers. They employ unnecessary business practices that they force employees to follow along with. They allow for minimal flexibility and their schedules are randomized. The managers all have a superiority complex over their peers and they always expect to be obeyed no matter how ridiculous the order they give is. They pay managers and extra 1-2 dollars per step they go up. The entire business is run based on incentives from corporate which makes each specific store manager want to push everyone even harder so they can look good in front of their higher ups. If you’re a cashier, don’t expect to sit down once your entire shift. Also if you’re sick or busy with things that are very important expect the managers to shame you and belittle you until they get what they want. Most stores will want you to come into work even if you have Covid. I wouldn’t even be surprised if they threatened to fire you if you called and told them you have to go to your own mothers funeral!! They are despicable, manipulative, and downright disrespectful. I took 35 minutes to try and reach an MOD once and the store kept redirecting me to random places around the store.

job_title: Merchandising Execution Associate in Helena, MT
pros: Great benefits for full time employees. Everyone gets profit sharing twice a year - amount is based on position, hours worked, and longevity. Take advantage of the discounted stock purchasing program if you can. Our store management really cared about and took care of all employees. Management frequently provided meals, treats, and small gifts to employees on holidays, special occasions, when goals are met, etc. If you like to work hard and do a good job, you will probably like this job. I found it very satisfying to set up new product displays and keep the shelves tidy and stocked.
cons: Be prepared to get dirty and sweaty, working all over the store inside and outside in all types of weather. MET metrics of achieving weekly goals are set very high and are often unachievable without taking shortcuts. Success and job satisfaction of the team is highly dependent on team management and store management. Fairly high employee turnover.

pros: Get success sharing every year based on how much we sell, Christmas party, and holiday pay is good. Made life time friends there.
cons: The amount of work and short staff that is there is horrible. Ive worked a lot of different retail places and big companies that don't acquire staffing to replace an associate puts major strain on the rest of the people there. You will be "Cross-Trained" meaning that you will learn each job and be expected to do each one to perfection. Unfortunately their system for orders is still horrible. They accept orders for pick up through out the day, 2 hours is supposed to be allowed per order. Instead of 2 ppl make an order at the same time you will have to pick both at the same time. This would be ok if the items were small or under 30 items, but it's lumber and concrete and shingles or tile which are all very hard to pick up let alone 60-200 pieces. The costumers there have expectations that are ridiculous, they expect you to drop everything to help them build a project for them or find an item that is on the next isle but won't look for it. Overall if you work this job expect to be outside when it's hot, cold, raining, snowing etc. Expect to be yelled at by costumers and your managers and your Manager's manager and everyone is in a cliche. There is always drama going on and can get toxic sometimes

pros: Of all the service industry jobs in my repertoire, The Home Depot treats me the best. The pay is low, but not unreasonable; I don't need to worry about making commissions, and I have access to a desk and chair when I need to sit down/rest.
cons: In my store, management fails to communicate effectively with each other or their employees. There is no on-hands training. I am the only specialist in my department, and I have only been a specialist for two months; only one manager has put in some effort to train me. Calling an MOD to solve an issue is like pulling teeth. They will either talk you through solving the issue (poorly, and despite the customer rejecting your input and wanting to speak directly to a manager) or won't answer calls for an MOD. Both MODs and employees hide and refuse to work outside their departments. More often than not, the store operates with a skeleton crew. Like in every retail job, customers are entitled and don't observe employees as real people. It is overall a stressful and joyless environment.

They have many programs claimed to be geared to helping their employees, eligibilities to apply for said programs are extreme and hardly met.
They will always take the customer's side no matter what. The customer can be lying about an interaction completely and you have multiple associates as witnesses to give a statement what really happened and the customer is still correct. 
When you are written up, ALWAYS write in your statement, KEEP your copy. 
If you have to write a statement for something, make and keep a copy. They will "LOSE" it when you ask for it so you have a more difficult time filling a lawsuit. 
Ask to see the notes in your file occasionally, upper management/suppervisors will write in there about conversations they have had with you that never acctually happened. All to cover their own hind and have a paper trail to fire you if you don't make the right friends. 
Company policies are not upheld to everyone, one person will get fired for something like not properly completing paperwork while the other who is a key carrier and dating their direct report will get promoted to store manager as well as their significant other get promoted to assistant manager and moved to another store so that makes their relationship kosher.

The company was started by great men with great things in mind, corporate has turned it into an extremely toxic environment. 
Talk to the employees at the store you're interviewing at before accepting a position! Get a feel for current management and district management first!

review_title: Just another unappreciated, underpaid retail sales role.
pros: Some decent coworkers but few and far between, you don't get dogged about sales numbers, no one breathing down your neck.
cons: I wouldn't recommend working here. There's never enough staff, the customers are abusive, the schedule is so inconsistent you can't keep track of what you work, you work mostly nights and weekends so you have no personal life, it's barely enough to scrape by in this economy, management never show when you page for help, the training is nonexistent, and they expect you to put on this fabricated personality to con people into buying more. It's exhausting work for little to no payoff. People gossip about you behind your back and they aren't as lgbtqia+ friendly and open to diversity as advertised. Basically, enjoy being thrown to the wolves, that's exactly what they do to you. They have a sink or swim mentality and it makes me sick. I choose to help build people up, not throw them in a river. I'm out, time to find another job and ghost. Home Depot, if you wanna retain good employees, you should make an effort to keep them. Everyone talks about how well I'm doing but management doesn't want to handle the issues that are pushing me out the door. And one other thing... We do NOT get paid enough to deal with customer abuse and if you don't plan to handle it, then people need to start calling the cops to hold these people accountable for their behavior.

review_title: MET: A low-paid, dead end job in Farmingdale, NY. Stay Away!
job_title: Merchandiser- MET Team in Farmingdale, NY
pros: Best day was when I walked out. Nuff said.
cons:
Worst job ever. Garbage management. MET at #1267 is like being at school - favorites and cliques exist. Coworkers ranged from friendly to psychotic.

The onboarding consisted of two days watching corporate videos The so-called training "coach" had attitude and thus was forced to ask coworkers everything. 

One co-worker verbally  threatened team members with violence and management ignored several complaints. Would result in termination elsewhere. This co-worker was not only retained, but later given an award. Management's favorites frequently late and/or absent with no repercussions while others get write-ups.

Have a shift scheduled before the store opens? Then be prepared to wait outside forever (in all sorts of weather) for management to unlock the door - even after scheduled start of shift!

No praise for hard work. Equipment missing, hidden or broken. Many of the orange ladders were faulty, unsafe and awkward to maneuver in narrow aisles often full with customers.

VERY ANTI-UNION. High level of supervision and monitoring, even during breaks and lunch. Extremely low pay for the amount of work required.  Pathetically low bonus and minimal pay increase while company and CEO make millions.  

Management uses threat of firing as a way to motivate workers during group meetings. Always expect to be busy and doing something, except for their chosen favourites who would often disappear.

 No staff discount and air conditioning during the hot Summer months. Supposed to be grateful for the occasional free sandwich every couple of weeks.

MET also answers customer inquiries and provides service because of dept call-outs or dept staff disappear - but it's the dept employees who get the Homer awards.

Dirty, Dusty, filthy and unsafe environment, work incompatible with wages, incompetent, abusive management, coupled with regular turnover of staff. No wonder the HIRING NOW signs are permanently displayed.

I’ve worked in multiple locations where this is the case. Most employees are starting to get run down for the extra weight they are carrying. A few good associates doing a whole stores job. Used to be a great company to work for when I started back in 2016.

review_title: Management is really hit or miss
pros: You have a lot of coworkers so statistically some of them will be cool people. They pay you on time every week.
cons:
Management is really hit or miss. There is very little training seemingly for management and a lot of decision for promotions seem to be made by the old adage of 'who you know not what you know.' This means that some managers are hilariously incompetent at their own job and have zero ability to manage employees well, while sometimes you get lucky and can have some really great managers.

Reverse ageism seems to be a thing too. If you are old you're literally expected to do nothing, instead everything the old folks should be doing but aren't is just shouldered onto younger associates. Also if you join the company and do nothing, they won't fire you or anything, just give up trying to get you to do anything and go back to lumping your workload on the people who actually do their jobs.

pros:
It is evident that The Home Depot cares about cultivating a positive company culture. Most people live up THD's values which are clearly and e�ffectively communicated to employees through multiple resources, initiatives, and incentives. I can con�fidently say that I had kind colleagues who worked hard to serve their customers well.

There's a bit of a learning curve in some departments but it's rewarding to gain specialized knowledge to help your customers. THD is serious about teaching people the ins and outs of the various departments. With enough training under your belt, it can be a relatively low-stress, low-drama place to work in non- management positions.
cons: The company policies and systems change often, and the changes are usually top- down (e.g. company-wide changes rather than store-based). Because of the top-down nature of changes, they might not make sense in real time at the ground-level. This leads to frustration and confusion for store employees. Top-down changes seem to be a constant for The Home Depot, but the pandemic definitely ramped up the frequency.

pros: Many colleagues are pleasant to work with.
cons: Don't work as a vendor at The Home Depot (THD) in Reading, MA. I was not a THD employee -- I was an employee of one of THD's vendor companies that supplies and maintains plants in THD's garden centers -- but I'm reviewing THD here (specifically the Reading branch) because THD management at this location frequently made the job a miserable experience. Their lack of support for vendors borders on hostility. They couldn't/wouldn't meet our basic needs, like consistent access to garden hoses with water in them, within reach of all of the plants. The position is similar to stocking groceries, but the shelves are always full. "Tell your boss not to order so many plants." (Sir, that's not my-) "DON'T TALK BACK" Plants dying right and left, some of mold and some of drought. Literally thousands more arrive every week, like there is zero communication between the store and the vendor sending the trucks over with more. Safety issues: A vendor's employee at a different THD location was seriously injured while trying to roll a new-plant-filled cart over a garden hose (the heavy cart tipped and fell on her). At this branch there's always at least one hose in your way, impossible to avoid them. These hoses are impulsively arranged and re-arranged by the hypersensitive, incompetent elderly THD employee tasked with designing and maintaining the constantly-malfunctioning system of watering equipment; hoses he's attached with automotive clamps, held down with zipties (!) are constantly tripping up vendors' carts as well as customers' shopping carts. The garden center supervisor on site rolls her eyes and says she doesn't care what he does. My own employer says, "Go ahead and disconnect them while you're rolling carts in, and re-connect them when you're finished". Then the Reading store manager, with a stunning lack of situational awareness says, "Under NO circumstances do you EVER touch a hose in my store- DO YOU HEAR ME? DON'T TALK BACK." None of this misery is necessary to the position. It's all about these specific people at this specific store. Avoid.

review_title: Manager need to know how to manage better.
pros:
The pros of working here,
1. Benefits.
2. 1-hour lunch break
3. Paid training.
cons:
There are so many cons.
1. The schedule they gave me was not a good one, I asked to be worked on Monday to Friday but they gave me Sunday and Wednesday off. 
2. On the first day of my job training, I was told that I would be a Customer greeter and lot associate. When one of the employees was giving a tour, she showed me the lot that I was supposed to be working for. when we got there, there were only two employees so customers were getting upset and frustrated because they had to wait longer than usual to get their order pick up. When we went to look for the manager, he wasn't there and when we called for help, he did not do a single thing. It was frustrating to see several cashiers just standing by when it was a self-checkout. They were just talking the whole time when some of them could have helped out. 
3. Manager needs to know how to manage and how to distribute workers evenly so that department isn't struggling. If there were several lot associates then things would have been a lot more smooth.
4. Hire more lot associates and fewer cashiers. 
5. You do not need a lot of cashiers when most of them are self-checkout.

review_title: Home Depot is a great company to work for
pros: - Promote from within -Bonuses - Treated professionally -Great job for young go getters
cons: -Long hours -Low pay -wear apron

pros: People I enjoy customers, I like other associates. They start to feel like family. They work around my schedule. I have another job because the pay if it were my only job, I’d have to live in my car. My daughter made more working at wal mart. Only managers make money at Home Depot. If you aren’t retired with a pension or living with your parents or a bunch of roommates. You could never make enough to survive. Seriously if I worked full time I still wouldn’t qualify to rent a decent apartment. Home Depot doesn’t pay well.
cons: There is one associate who interrupts conversations with customers. Is a rude know it all, makes up stories to other associates, name calls to associates. Gives dirty looks, tries to make customers feel stupid. Customers have complained to other associates, but not to management. This associate worked at another local Home Depot and I heard from A rep that they were glad to get rid of her. Now she’s our problem. A real manipulative person, manipulates our 22 year old kid supervisor. She doesn’t have enough work experience to understand she’s being manipulated. It’s almost sad, in my 30 years of working, this is by far the most unprofessional work environment I’ve been in. The thing is they claim a open door work environment is what they have. But for some reason no one wants to step up and vocalize what she does. They are upset, but are unwilling to come forward. Maybe they see she’s mentally unstable and if she got fired she’d come in and shoot the place up. It’s like it’s all she has in her life, but she’s not a full timer. As much as I really love it there other than this unstable associate. I feel a connection to 90 percent of the staff, we have some real good people. I don’t think management is willing to do the right thing. Customers should be the most important thing. This associate really doesn’t understand that. She’s worried about things like the paint counter having paint on it, and violently scrapping paint off in front on a brand new associate, making him rethink staying there. I’ve seen some real bizarre behavior. At the Home Depot one person saying it they disregard it. You have to have multi people come forward.

Depending on the management you work with, favoritism can slow you down significantly even if you have all the skills necessary and have passed their designated tests to become promoted.

Literally had a store Manager (hired from outside the company ) tell me I was the best thing on earth one week and as a good supervisor I asked what I can improve on they said nothing and then the next week tell me I was the worst thing on earth and wasn’t promotable. Luckily their is always a witness during these conversations and I did mention how is this possible when last week both of them the store manager and assistant store manager were in the same room stating the complete opposite and they both had nothing to say

It’s sad to say but I can certainly say knowing my job title and my duties were vital due to this store manager not knowing much would lie and make things up to to try and get me out of the store I owe it to the previous store manager who thought me all the metrics I know and my work ethic to holding down my position.

pros:
(1) The Home Depot gives good exposure activity by coordinating the front end cashier department with other departments so that customer check out experience becomes easy, leases burdensome and with high probability of return of the customer.

(2) The Home Depot also provide the cross training in various departments which ultimately paves the way of the growth within the company.

(3) The working experience at Home Depot is so good and healthy that you can learn from anyone and can be clear and open to anyone regarding your conditions like harassment, concerns or questions and the things are really solved within proper procedures and timely fashion.
cons: (1) The major disadvantage from my perspective as an international student here in Canada is that Home Depot lacks the help that student requires for his/ her immigration status like work permit or permanent residence.
